sn12.50:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, a learned noble disciple doesn’t think:

sn12.50:1.3.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho kismiṃ sati kiṃ hoti, kissuppādā kiṃ uppajjati?
sn12.50:1.3.eng: ‘When what exists, what is? Due to the arising of what, what arises?

sn12.50:1.4.pli: Kismiṃ sati saṅkhārā honti, kismiṃ sati viññāṇaṃ hoti, kismiṃ sati nāmarūpaṃ hoti, kismiṃ sati saḷāyatanaṃ hoti, kismiṃ sati phasso hoti, kismiṃ sati vedanā hoti, kismiṃ sati taṇhā hoti, kismiṃ sati upādānaṃ hoti, kismiṃ sati bhavo hoti, kismiṃ sati jāti hoti, kismiṃ sati jarāmaraṇaṃ hotī’ti?
sn12.50:1.4.eng: When what exists do choices come to be? When what exists does consciousness come to be? When what exists do name and form … the six sense fields … contact … feeling … craving … grasping … continued existence … rebirth … old age and death come to be?’

sn12.50:2.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sutavato ariyasāvakassa aparappaccayā ñāṇamevettha hoti:
sn12.50:2.1.eng: Rather, a learned noble disciple has only knowledge about this that is independent of others:

sn12.50:2.2.pli: ‘imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjati.
sn12.50:2.2.eng: ‘When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises.

sn12.50:2.3.eng: When ignorance exists, choices come to be.

sn12.50:2.4.eng: When choices exist consciousness comes to be.

sn12.50:2.5.eng: When consciousness exists name and form come to be.

sn12.50:2.6.eng: When name and form exist the six sense fields come to be.

sn12.50:2.7.eng: When the six sense fields exist contact comes to be.

sn12.50:2.8.eng: When contact exists feeling comes to be.

sn12.50:2.9.eng: When feeling exists craving comes to be.

sn12.50:2.10.eng: When craving exists grasping comes to be.

sn12.50:2.11.eng: When grasping exists continued existence comes to be.

sn12.50:2.12.eng: When continued existence exists rebirth comes to be.

sn12.50:2.13.eng: When rebirth exists old age and death come to be.’

sn12.50:3.1.pli: Na, bhikkhave, sutavato ariyasāvakassa evaṃ hoti:
sn12.50:3.1.eng: A learned noble disciple doesn’t think:

sn12.50:3.2.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho kismiṃ asati kiṃ na hoti, kissa nirodhā kiṃ nirujjhati?
sn12.50:3.2.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist, what is not? Due to the cessation of what, what ceases?

sn12.50:3.3.pli: Kismiṃ asati saṅkhārā na honti, kismiṃ asati viññāṇaṃ na hoti, kismiṃ asati nāmarūpaṃ na hoti, kismiṃ asati saḷāyatanaṃ na hoti, kismiṃ asati phasso na hoti, kismiṃ asati vedanā na hoti, kismiṃ asati taṇhā na hoti …pe…
sn12.50:3.3.eng: When what doesn’t exist do choices not come to be? When what doesn’t exist does consciousness not come to be? When what doesn’t exist do name and form … the six sense fields … contact … feeling … craving … grasping … continued existence … rebirth … old age and death not come to be?’

sn12.50:4.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sutavato ariyasāvakassa aparappaccayā ñāṇamevettha hoti:
sn12.50:4.1.eng: Rather, a learned noble disciple has only knowledge about this that is independent of others:

sn12.50:4.2.pli: ‘imasmiṃ asati idaṃ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhati.
sn12.50:4.2.eng: ‘When this doesn’t exist, this doesn’t come to be; due to the cessation of this, this ceases. That is:

sn12.50:4.3.eng: When ignorance doesn’t exists, choices don’t come to be.

sn12.50:4.4.eng: When choices don’t exist consciousness doesn’t come to be.

sn12.50:4.5.eng: When consciousness doesn’t exist name and form don’t come to be.

sn12.50:4.6.eng: When name and form don’t exist the six sense fields don’t come to be. …

sn12.50:4.7.eng: When rebirth doesn’t exist old age and death don’t come to be.’

sn12.50:5.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ lokassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako diṭṭhisampanno itipi, dassanasampanno itipi, āgato imaṃ saddhammaṃ itipi, passati imaṃ saddhammaṃ itipi, sekkhena ñāṇena samannāgato itipi, sekkhāya vijjāya samannāgato itipi, dhammasotaṃ samāpanno itipi, ariyo nibbedhikapañño itipi, amatadvāraṃ āhacca tiṭṭhati itipī”ti.
sn12.50:5.1.eng: A noble disciple comes to truly understand the origin and ending of the world. Such a noble disciple is one who is called ‘one accomplished in view’, ‘one accomplished in vision’, ‘one who has come to the true teaching’, ‘one who sees this true teaching’, ‘one endowed with a trainee’s knowledge’, ‘one who has entered the stream of the teaching’, ‘a noble one with penetrative wisdom’, and also ‘one who stands pressing against the door to freedom from death’.”

sn12.51:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn12.51:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn12.51:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn12.51:2.1.pli: “Kittāvatā nu kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu parivīmaṃsamāno parivīmaṃseyya sabbaso sammā dukkhakkhayāyā”ti?
sn12.51:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a mendicant is inquiring, how do you define when they are inquiring for the complete ending of suffering?”

sn12.51:2.2.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
sn12.51:2.2.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

sn12.51:2.3.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn12.51:2.3.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn12.51:2.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn12.51:3.1.eng: “Mendicants, take a mendicant who makes an inquiry:
sn12.51:3.1.comm: Pali is rich in expressions for inner reflection and investigation. Sometimes this process is called “inner self-examination” (SN 12.66:3.3, sometimes “rational application of mind” (SN 12.4:2.3).

sn12.51:3.2.pli: ‘yaṃ kho idaṃ anekavidhaṃ nānappakārakaṃ dukkhaṃ loke uppajjati jarāmaraṇaṃ;
sn12.51:3.2.eng: ‘The suffering that arises in the world starting with old age and death takes many and diverse forms.

sn12.51:3.3.pli: idaṃ nu kho dukkhaṃ kiṃnidānaṃ kiṃsamudayaṃ kiṃjātikaṃ kiṃpabhavaṃ?
sn12.51:3.3.eng: What is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of this suffering?

sn12.51:3.4.pli: Kismiṃ sati jarāmaraṇaṃ hoti, kismiṃ asati jarāmaraṇaṃ na hotī’ti?
sn12.51:3.4.eng: When what exists do old age and death come to be? When what does not exist do old age and death not come to be?’

sn12.51:3.5.eng: While making an inquiry they understand:

sn12.51:3.6.pli: ‘yaṃ kho idaṃ anekavidhaṃ nānappakārakaṃ dukkhaṃ loke uppajjati jarāmaraṇaṃ, idaṃ kho dukkhaṃ jātinidānaṃ jātisamudayaṃ jātijātikaṃ jātippabhavaṃ.
sn12.51:3.6.eng: ‘The suffering that arises in the world starting with old age and death takes many and diverse forms. The source of this suffering is rebirth.

sn12.51:3.7.pli: Jātiyā sati jarāmaraṇaṃ hoti, jātiyā asati jarāmaraṇaṃ na hotī’ti.
sn12.51:3.7.eng: When rebirth exists, old age and death come to be. When rebirth doesn’t exist, old age and death don’t come to be.’

sn12.51:4.1.pli: So jarāmaraṇañca pajānāti, jarāmaraṇasamudayañca pajānāti, jarāmaraṇanirodhañca pajānāti, yā ca jarāmaraṇanirodhasāruppagāminī paṭipadā tañca pajānāti, tathā paṭipanno ca hoti anudhammacārī;
sn12.51:4.1.eng: They understand old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the fitting practice for their cessation. And they practice in line with that path.

sn12.51:4.2.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso sammā dukkhakkhayāya paṭipanno jarāmaraṇanirodhāya.
sn12.51:4.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who is practicing for the complete ending of suffering, for the cessation of old age and death.

sn12.51:5.2.pli: ‘jāti panāyaṃ kiṃnidānā kiṃsamudayā kiṃjātikā kiṃpabhavā, kismiṃ sati jāti hoti, kismiṃ asati jāti na hotī’ti?
sn12.51:5.2.eng: ‘But what is the source of this rebirth? When what exists does rebirth come to be? And when what does not exist does rebirth not come to be?’

sn12.51:5.3.eng: While making an inquiry they understand:

sn12.51:5.4.eng: ‘Continued existence is the source of rebirth.

sn12.51:5.5.pli: bhave sati jāti hoti, bhave asati jāti na hotī’ti.
sn12.51:5.5.eng: When continued existence exists, rebirth comes to be. When continued existence does not exist, rebirth doesn’t come to be.’

sn12.51:6.1.pli: So jātiñca pajānāti, jātisamudayañca pajānāti, jātinirodhañca pajānāti, yā ca jātinirodhasāruppagāminī paṭipadā tañca pajānāti, tathā paṭipanno ca hoti anudhammacārī;
sn12.51:6.1.eng: They understand rebirth, its origin, its cessation, and the fitting practice for its cessation. And they practice in line with that path.

sn12.51:6.2.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso sammā dukkhakkhayāya paṭipanno jātinirodhāya.
sn12.51:6.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who is practicing for the complete ending of suffering, for the cessation of rebirth.

sn12.51:7.2.eng: ‘But what is the source of this continued existence? …’ …

sn12.51:7.3.eng: ‘But what is the source of this grasping? …’ …

sn12.51:7.4.eng: ‘But what is the source of this craving? …’ …

sn12.51:7.5.eng: ‘But what is the source of this feeling? …’ …

sn12.51:7.6.eng: ‘But what is the source of this contact? …’ …

sn12.51:7.7.eng: ‘But what is the source of these six sense fields? …’ …

sn12.51:7.8.eng: ‘But what is the source of this name and form? …’ …

sn12.51:7.9.eng: ‘But what is the source of this consciousness? …’ …

sn12.51:7.10.pli: saṅkhārā panime kiṃnidānā kiṃsamudayā kiṃjātikā kiṃpabhavā;
sn12.51:7.10.eng: ‘But what is the source of these choices?

sn12.51:7.11.pli: kismiṃ sati saṅkhārā honti, kismiṃ asati saṅkhārā na hontī’ti?
sn12.51:7.11.eng: When what exists do choices come to be? When what does not exist do choices not come to be?’

sn12.51:7.12.eng: While making an inquiry they understand:

sn12.51:7.14.pli: avijjāya sati saṅkhārā honti, avijjāya asati saṅkhārā na hontī’ti.
sn12.51:7.14.eng: When ignorance exists, choices come to be. When ignorance does not exist, choices don’t come to be.’

sn12.51:8.1.pli: So saṅkhāre ca pajānāti, saṅkhārasamudayañca pajānāti, saṅkhāranirodhañca pajānāti, yā ca saṅkhāranirodhasāruppagāminī paṭipadā tañca pajānāti, tathā paṭipanno ca hoti anudhammacārī;
sn12.51:8.1.eng: They understand choices, their origin, their cessation, and the fitting practice for their cessation. And they practice in line with that path.

sn12.51:8.2.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso sammā dukkhakkhayāya paṭipanno saṅkhāranirodhāya.
sn12.51:8.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who is practicing for the complete ending of suffering, for the cessation of choices.

sn12.51:9.1.pli: Avijjāgato yaṃ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalo puññañce saṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, puññūpagaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ.
sn12.51:9.1.eng: If an ignorant individual makes a good choice, consciousness passes on by means of goodness.
sn12.51:9.1.comm: This is one of the passages showing that the primary sense of saṅkhāra is moral “choices” either good, bad, or “imperturbable”. See also MN 57:9.2, AN 3.23, AN 4.233. | The suffix -upaga indicates “passing on” to rebirth in a new life. The compound puññūpaga parallels kammupaga and means “passes on by means of goodness” (resolve to puññena upagataṁ).

sn12.51:9.2.pli: Apuññañce saṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, apuññūpagaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ.
sn12.51:9.2.eng: If they make a bad choice, consciousness passes on by means of badness.

sn12.51:9.3.pli: Āneñjañce saṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti āneñjūpagaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ.
sn12.51:9.3.eng: If they make an imperturbable choice, consciousness passes on by means of imperturbability.
sn12.51:9.3.comm: The fourth absorption and above are called “imperturbable” (āneñja) because they are associated with equanimous feeling. This is technically distinguished from “good” or “meritorious” (puñña) choices, whose outcome is pleasant feeling.

sn12.51:9.4.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno avijjā pahīnā hoti vijjā uppannā, so avijjāvirāgā vijjuppādā neva puññābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti na apuññābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti na āneñjābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti.
sn12.51:9.4.eng: When a mendicant has given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, with the fading away of ignorance and the arising of knowledge they don’t make a good choice, a bad choice, or an imperturbable choice.
sn12.51:9.4.comm: This shows that the sense of “choices” here is morally pregnant: they make no choice productive of future lives. They still make “choices” which are in line with the good, they just don’t have any kammic effect.

sn12.51:9.5.pli: Anabhisaṅkharonto anabhisañcetayanto na kiñci loke upādiyati;
sn12.51:9.5.eng: Not choosing or intending, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.

sn12.51:9.6.pli: anupādiyaṃ na paritassati, aparitassaṃ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati.
sn12.51:9.6.eng: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
sn12.51:9.6.comm: Letting go is not just a conceptual matter, it has immediate emotional consequences. Paritassati conveys the twin senses of desire and agitation, for which “anxiety” seems the best fit.

sn12.51:9.7.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
sn12.51:9.7.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

sn12.51:10.1.pli: So sukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā aniccāti pajānāti, anajjhositāti pajānāti, anabhinanditāti pajānāti.
sn12.51:10.1.eng: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.
sn12.51:10.1.comm: This describes the reflective experience of the arahant.

sn12.51:10.2.pli: Dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā aniccāti pajānāti, anajjhositāti pajānāti, anabhinanditāti pajānāti.
sn12.51:10.2.eng: If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.

sn12.51:10.3.pli: Adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā aniccāti pajānāti, anajjhositāti pajānāti, anabhinanditāti pajānāti.
sn12.51:10.3.eng: If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.

sn12.51:10.4.pli: So sukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaṃyutto naṃ vedayati.
sn12.51:10.4.eng: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.

sn12.51:10.5.pli: Dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaṃyutto naṃ vedayati.
sn12.51:10.5.eng: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.

sn12.51:10.6.pli: Adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaṃyutto naṃ vedayati.
sn12.51:10.6.eng: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.

sn12.51:11.1.pli: So kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmīti pajānāti, jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmīti pajānāti.
sn12.51:11.1.eng: Feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’

sn12.51:11.2.pli: Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissanti, sarīrāni avasissantīti pajānāti.
sn12.51:11.2.eng: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here. Only bodily remains will be left.’
sn12.51:11.2.comm: To “become cool” is, as the simile makes clear, to realize extinguishment (nibbāna).

sn12.51:12.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso kumbhakārapākā uṇhaṃ kumbhaṃ uddharitvā same bhūmibhāge paṭisisseyya.
sn12.51:12.1.eng: Suppose a person were to remove a hot clay pot from a potter’s kiln and place it down on level ground.

sn12.51:12.2.pli: Tatra yāyaṃ usmā sā tattheva vūpasameyya, kapallāni avasisseyyuṃ.
sn12.51:12.2.eng: Its heat would dissipate right there, and the shards would be left behind.

sn12.51:12.3.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmīti pajānāti, jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmīti pajānāti.
sn12.51:12.3.eng: In the same way, feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’

sn12.51:12.4.pli: Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissanti, sarīrāni avasissantīti pajānāti.
sn12.51:12.4.eng: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here. Only bodily remains will be left.’

sn12.51:13.2.pli: api nu kho khīṇāsavo bhikkhu puññābhisaṅkhāraṃ vā abhisaṅkhareyya apuññābhisaṅkhāraṃ vā abhisaṅkhareyya āneñjābhisaṅkhāraṃ vā abhisaṅkhareyyā”ti?
sn12.51:13.2.eng: Would a mendicant who has ended the defilements still make good choices, bad choices, or imperturbable choices?”

sn12.51:14.1.pli: “Sabbaso vā pana saṅkhāresu asati, saṅkhāranirodhā api nu kho viññāṇaṃ paññāyethā”ti?
sn12.51:14.1.eng: “And when there are no choices at all, with the cessation of choices, would consciousness still be found?”

sn12.51:15.1.pli: “Sabbaso vā pana viññāṇe asati, viññāṇanirodhā api nu kho nāmarūpaṃ paññāyethā”ti?
sn12.51:15.1.eng: “And when there’s no consciousness at all, would name and form still be found?”

sn12.51:16.1.pli: “Sabbaso vā pana nāmarūpe asati, nāmarūpanirodhā api nu kho saḷāyatanaṃ paññāyethā”ti?
sn12.51:16.1.eng: “And when there are no name and form at all, would the six sense fields still be found?”

sn12.51:17.1.pli: “Sabbaso vā pana saḷāyatane asati, saḷāyatananirodhā api nu kho phasso paññāyethā”ti?
sn12.51:17.1.eng: “And when there are no six sense fields at all, would contact still be found?”

sn12.51:18.1.pli: “Sabbaso vā pana phasse asati, phassanirodhā api nu kho vedanā paññāyethā”ti?
sn12.51:18.1.eng: “And when there’s no contact at all, would feeling still be found?”

sn12.51:19.1.pli: “Sabbaso vā pana vedanāya asati, vedanānirodhā api nu kho taṇhā paññāyethā”ti?
sn12.51:19.1.eng: “And when there’s no feeling at all, would craving still be found?”

sn12.51:20.1.pli: “Sabbaso vā pana taṇhāya asati, taṇhānirodhā api nu kho upādānaṃ paññāyethā”ti?
sn12.51:20.1.eng: “And when there’s no craving at all, would grasping still be found?”

sn12.51:21.1.pli: “Sabbaso vā pana upādāne asati, upādānanirodhā api nu kho bhavo paññāyethā”ti.
sn12.51:21.1.eng: “And when there’s no grasping at all, would continued existence still be found?”

sn12.51:22.1.pli: “Sabbaso vā pana bhave asati, bhavanirodhā api nu kho jāti paññāyethā”ti?
sn12.51:22.1.eng: “And when there’s no continued existence at all, would rebirth still be found?”

sn12.51:23.1.pli: “Sabbaso vā pana jātiyā asati, jātinirodhā api nu kho jarāmaraṇaṃ paññāyethā”ti?
sn12.51:23.1.eng: “And when there’s no rebirth at all, would old age and death still be found?”

sn12.51:24.1.pli: “Sādhu sādhu, bhikkhave, evametaṃ, bhikkhave, netaṃ aññathā.
sn12.51:24.1.eng: “Good, good, mendicants! That’s how it is, not otherwise.

sn12.51:24.2.pli: Saddahatha me taṃ, bhikkhave, adhimuccatha, nikkaṅkhā ettha hotha nibbicikicchā.
sn12.51:24.2.eng: Trust me on this, mendicants; be convinced. Have no doubts or uncertainties in this matter.

sn12.51:24.3.eng: Just this is the end of suffering.”

sn12.52:1.2.pli: “Upādāniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu assādānupassino viharato taṇhā pavaḍḍhati.
sn12.52:1.2.eng: “There are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, your craving grows.
sn12.52:1.2.comm: Upādāniya is literally “graspable”. The simile evokes the secondary sense of upādāna as “fuel”, so I translate “(things that) fuel grasping”.

sn12.52:1.3.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

sn12.52:1.4.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

sn12.52:1.5.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

sn12.52:1.6.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

sn12.52:1.7.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.52:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dasannaṃ vā kaṭṭhavāhānaṃ vīsāya vā kaṭṭhavāhānaṃ tiṃsāya vā kaṭṭhavāhānaṃ cattārīsāya vā kaṭṭhavāhānaṃ mahāaggikkhandho jaleyya.
sn12.52:2.1.eng: Suppose a great mass of fire was burning with ten, twenty, thirty, or forty loads of wood.

sn12.52:2.2.pli: Tatra puriso kālena kālaṃ sukkhāni ceva tiṇāni pakkhipeyya, sukkhāni ca gomayāni pakkhipeyya, sukkhāni ca kaṭṭhāni pakkhipeyya.
sn12.52:2.2.eng: And from time to time someone would toss in dry grass, cow dung, or wood.

sn12.52:2.3.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, mahāaggikkhandho tadāhāro tadupādāno ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ jaleyya.
sn12.52:2.3.eng: Fed and fuelled by that, the great mass of fire would burn for a long time.

sn12.52:2.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, upādāniyesu dhammesu assādānupassino viharato taṇhā pavaḍḍhati.
sn12.52:2.4.eng: In the same way, there are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, your craving grows.

sn12.52:2.5.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping. …

sn12.52:2.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.52:3.1.pli: Upādāniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato taṇhā nirujjhati.
sn12.52:3.1.eng: There are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, your craving ceases.

sn12.52:3.3.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

sn12.52:3.4.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

sn12.52:3.5.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

sn12.52:3.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.52:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dasannaṃ vā kaṭṭhavāhānaṃ vīsāya vā tiṃsāya vā cattārīsāya vā kaṭṭhavāhānaṃ mahāaggikkhandho jaleyya;
sn12.52:4.1.eng: Suppose a great mass of fire was burning with ten, twenty, thirty, or forty loads of wood.

sn12.52:4.2.pli: tatra puriso na kālena kālaṃ sukkhāni ceva tiṇāni pakkhipeyya, na sukkhāni ca gomayāni pakkhipeyya, na sukkhāni ca kaṭṭhāni pakkhipeyya.
sn12.52:4.2.eng: And no-one would toss in dry grass, cow dung, or wood from time to time.

sn12.52:4.3.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, mahāaggikkhandho purimassa ca upādānassa pariyādānā aññassa ca anupahārā anāhāro nibbāyeyya.
sn12.52:4.3.eng: As the original fuel is used up and no more is added, the great mass of fire would be extinguished due to not being fed.

sn12.52:4.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, upādāniyesu dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato taṇhā nirujjhati,
sn12.52:4.4.eng: In the same way, there are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, your craving ceases.

sn12.52:4.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

sn12.53:1.2.pli: “Saṃyojaniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu assādānupassino viharato taṇhā pavaḍḍhati.
sn12.53:1.2.eng: “There are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, your craving grows.
sn12.53:1.2.comm: The fetters are desire and lust, the “things that tighten the fetters” (saṁyojaniya dhamma) are the pleasures afforded by the senses (SN 35.122).

sn12.53:1.3.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

sn12.53:1.4.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

sn12.53:1.5.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

sn12.53:1.6.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

sn12.53:1.7.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.53:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, telañca paṭicca vaṭṭiñca paṭicca telappadīpo jhāyeyya.
sn12.53:2.1.eng: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.

sn12.53:2.2.pli: Tatra puriso kālena kālaṃ telaṃ āsiñceyya vaṭṭiṃ upasaṃhareyya.
sn12.53:2.2.eng: And from time to time someone would pour oil in and adjust the wick.

sn12.53:2.3.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, telappadīpo tadāhāro tadupādāno ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ jaleyya.
sn12.53:2.3.eng: Fed and fuelled by that, the oil lamp would burn for a long time.

sn12.53:2.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, saṃyojaniyesu dhammesu assādānupassino viharato taṇhā pavaḍḍhati.
sn12.53:2.4.eng: In the same way, there are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, your craving grows.

sn12.53:2.5.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

sn12.53:2.6.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

sn12.53:2.7.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

sn12.53:2.8.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

sn12.53:2.9.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.53:3.1.pli: Saṃyojaniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato taṇhā nirujjhati.
sn12.53:3.1.eng: There are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, your craving ceases.

sn12.53:3.3.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

sn12.53:3.4.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

sn12.53:3.5.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

sn12.53:3.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.53:4.2.eng: And no-one would pour oil in and adjust the wick from time to time.

sn12.53:4.3.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, telappadīpo purimassa ca upādānassa pariyādānā aññassa ca anupahārā anāhāro nibbāyeyya.

sn12.53:4.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

sn12.55:1.2.pli: “Upādāniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu assādānupassino viharato taṇhā pavaḍḍhati.
sn12.55:1.2.eng: “There are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, your craving grows.

sn12.55:1.3.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

sn12.55:1.4.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence. …

sn12.55:1.5.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.55:2.1.eng: Suppose there was a great tree.

sn12.55:2.2.pli: Tassa yāni ceva mūlāni adhogamāni, yāni ca tiriyaṅgamāni, sabbāni tāni uddhaṃ ojaṃ abhiharanti.
sn12.55:2.2.eng: And its roots going downwards and across all draw the sap upwards.

sn12.55:2.3.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, mahārukkho tadāhāro tadupādāno ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭheyya.
sn12.55:2.3.eng: Fed and fuelled by that, the great tree would stand for a long time.

sn12.55:2.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, upādāniyesu dhammesu assādānupassino viharato taṇhā pavaḍḍhati.
sn12.55:2.4.eng: In the same way, there are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, your craving grows.

sn12.55:2.5.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping. …

sn12.55:2.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.55:3.1.pli: Upādāniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato taṇhā nirujjhati.
sn12.55:3.1.eng: There are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, your craving ceases.

sn12.55:3.3.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. …

sn12.55:3.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.55:4.1.eng: Suppose there was a great tree.

sn12.55:4.2.eng: Then a person comes along with a spade and basket.

sn12.55:4.3.pli: So taṃ rukkhaṃ mūle chindeyya, mūlaṃ chinditvā palikhaṇeyya, palikhaṇitvā mūlāni uddhareyya antamaso usīranāḷimattānipi.
sn12.55:4.3.eng: They’d cut the tree down at the roots, dig it up, and pull the roots out, down to the fibers and stems.

sn12.55:4.4.pli: So taṃ rukkhaṃ khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ chindeyya, khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ chinditvā phāleyya, phāletvā sakalikaṃ sakalikaṃ kareyya, sakalikaṃ sakalikaṃ karitvā vātātape visoseyya;
sn12.55:4.4.eng: They’d cut the tree apart, cut up the parts, and chop it into splinters. They’d dry the splinters in the wind and sun, burn them with fire, and reduce them to ashes. Then they’d winnow the ashes in a strong wind, or float them away down a swift stream.

sn12.55:4.5.pli: vātātape visosetvā agginā ḍaheyya, agginā ḍahetvā masiṃ kareyya, masiṃ karitvā mahāvāte vā ophuṇeyya nadiyā vā sīghasotāya pavāheyya.

sn12.55:4.6.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, mahārukkho ucchinnamūlo assa tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.
sn12.55:4.6.eng: In this way the great tree is cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn12.55:4.7.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, upādāniyesu dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato taṇhā nirujjhati.
sn12.55:4.7.eng: In the same way, there are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, your craving ceases.

sn12.55:4.9.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. …

sn12.55:4.10.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”
